Award.AwardTitle: Symposium: Participant Travel Support for the 89th ACS Colloid and Surface Science Symposium, June 15-17, 2015, Pittsburgh, PA

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1523306
PI: Schneider, James

This project will support the participation of US scientists and engineers in the 89th American Chemical Society Colloid and Surface Science Symposium, which will be held on the campus of Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh, PA from June 15-17, 2015. The symposium will address a broad range of topics in colloidal and surface science that are broadly relevant to many processes of technological and biological interest. The symposium will provide a way for leading research groups to interact with researchers across academic and scientific disciplines, and it will help junior researchers, including young faculty members and graduate students, to interact with leaders in the field.

This symposium, which will consist of a variety of keynote lectures, technical and poster sessions, will cover a variety of timely and innovative themes that are central to recent advances in colloidal and surface science. The topics of planned sessions include self- and directed-assembly of nanomaterials, dynamics of suspensions, nanoscale imaging and spectroscopy of interfaces, the behavior of polymers under confinement, electrokinetics and microfluidics, and the role of colloidal principles in environmental systems and in nanomedicine.

The 89th American Chemical Society Colloid and Surface Science Symposium, sponsored by the ACS Division of Colloid and Surface Chemistry, was held at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, from June 14 – 17, 2015.  The sponsors included twelve corporate sponsors, seven extramural sponsors, and seven sponsors within Carnegie Mellon University.  The Symposium was co-organized by Professors Stephen Garoff, James Schneider and Robert Tilton of Carnegie Mellon University.  Plenary lectures were given by Professor David Pine of New York University and Professor Tejal Desai of the University of California at San Francisco.  The Victor K. LaMer Award Lecture was presented by Dr. Qian Chen, now at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign.  The Unilever Award Lecture was presented by Professor Jill Millstone of the University of Pittsburgh.  

The Symposium began with a welcoming reception on Sunday evening. Technical sessions in eight to eleven parallel sessions occurred through the day.  While posters were on display throughout the meeting, the official poster session and reception was on Monday evening.  Four student poster awards were given, including a People’s Choice Award selected on the basis of poster session attendee voting.  Tuesday’s program began with Professor Tejal Desai’s plenary lecture, “Hierarchical interfaces for overcoming drug delivery barriers”.  The day continued with parallel technical sessions and ended with Professor Millstone’s Unilever Award lecture, “Impact of surface chemistry in multimetallic nanoparticle synthesis and performance”.  Tuesday’s program ended with the conference banquet held at the Carnegie Museum of Art and Natural History with dessert served among the exhibits.  Professor Chen’s LaMer Award Lecture began the final day of the conference.  Technical sessions ended at 5 PM on Wednesday.

In addition to the plenary and award lectures, the technical program consisted of 442 oral presentations and 84 poster presentations in 13 symposia. Each symposium had two co-organizers, as listed in Appendix 2.  18 of the 28 academic organizers were from institutions other than Carnegie Mellon, including two from Sweden, two from Canada, one from Finland and one from Switzerland.  Three organizers were from U.S. national laboratories. Each technical symposium featured two invited keynote speakers who were allotted a double time-slot for presentation. Keynote speakers were from the U.S. and six other nations, and included speakers from academia, national laboratories and industry.  The list of technical symposia was formally vetted by the Symposium Committee at the June 2013 business meeting in time to be announced at the 2014 Symposium.

The technical program was complemented by an Instrument Exhibition, featuring staffed displays by Biolin Scientific, CPS Instruments, Dispersion Technology, Formulaction, Future Digital Scientific Corporation, Insplorion, Krüss, Kyowa, Laval Lab, Malvern Instruments, Micromeritics, Particle Sizing Systems, Solvay, Visitech International, and Wyatt Technology. Exhibitors were charged $2000 and were given one free registration, a ten-foot by ten-foot space for their booth, with a six-foot long table and two chairs. The net revenue per exhibitor after the reduction by the cost of their complimentary registration was $1635.  The Exhibition ran from Monday afternoon through Wednesday afternoon in the University Center gymnasium.
